public class CryptoHash
extends Object
The only reason this is not GUEST is that System.loadLibrary is not available to GUESTs. If we move that load elsewhere we could make this GUEST.

CryptoHash 
  public CryptoHash(byte bytes[])
Constructor to return aa CryptoHash given a byte array representing an object. These byte arrays are typically created using a seralizer.
Parameters:
bytes - untrusted nullOK - A byte array. However, if given as null, then we construct a special object, known as a nullCryptoHash object.

hashCode 
  public int hashCode()
Given a cryptohash byte array, compute and return a hashcode (an int) for it. Since we are dealing with Cryptohashes we know we can just grab four bytes at the start of the array and use that as a hashcode with *excellent* distribution.
Overrides:
hashCode in class Object
equals 
  public boolean equals(Object object)
Our equality predicate. We are equal to any other CryptoHash object with the same CryptoHash contents, byte for byte.
Parameters:
object - untrusted nullOk - something to compare ourselves to.
Overrides:
equals in class Object
nullCryptoHash 
  public static CryptoHash nullCryptoHash()
Return the singleton instance of a CryptoHash that we use to represent null data.
toString 
  public String toString()
Returns a printable string - We show enough of the bytes to give us a semi-unique hint of the contents. Note that the result ignores all but the first four (4) bytes. This number is hardcoded into into byteArrayToAbbreviatedHexString and above in the constructor when given a null argument.
Overrides:
toString in class Object
asHex 
  public String asHex()
Return a string of hex characters based on the contents of the entire array.
computeCryptoHashForBytes 
  public static byte[] computeCryptoHashForBytes(byte dataBytes[])
Given a byte array, compute and return a cryptohash for it. We make this available as a static method since it's generally useful and convesy no authority.a
main 
  public static void main(String argv[])
main() - for testing.
